Actually, the Universe, not Earth, is 13.7by old. A basic way to calculate this is by measuring the rate of the expansion of space and calculating the time back to the point when all the matter was in one place, called a singularity.

Just as a note I'm not trying to be mean or irritating by explaining the star stuff and I'm not arguing with what you said about creation, just the part you said about black holes. I just love the subject of astronomy and just thought I'd ramble for a bit and teach you something you might not have known before.

Star death part 3 (last one I promise): Sometimes though the mass of the star is so insane  that the explosion from the supernova isn't big enough to stop the collapse and compression. It continues anyway. It crushes all that matter into a single point in space that we call a black hole. So not all stars become a black hole, only the most massive ones do. Most stars don't get that far and instead explode as supernovas (lighter stars can form other things too, but i skipped talking about those).

Star death part 2: So the star is dying. It's run out of its normal fuel(hydrogen) and is using other fuel instead(Helium) to make larger elements(it can make up to Iron this way). At this point the fuel just can't ignite and drive the reaction any longer, the star collapses. It starts shrinking. Sometimes this insane compression can get that Iron to react finally, forming even larger atoms like Uranium, but it also causes a huge explosion that rips the star apart, called a supernova.

And we came to that conclusion how? Because we were trying to find the origins of our universe. But the universe has always been here. If it wasn't, that's nothing. So where did the building blocks come from?

A bit of info about star death: What happens to a star when it dies depends on the size (mass) of the star. You know stars fuse Hydrogen atoms (the simplest atom) into Helium and that releases energy. When a star runs low on Hydrogen (this takes a long time usually) it will start fusing the helium it had created together instead of the hydrogen. This forms even larger elements like oxygen and carbon and sulfur, but this reaction doesn't release quite as much energy so the star loses stability.

Yes, fusion beyond iron is not an energy producer, but that needn't mean it can't happen. All it means is that it is a process that once invoked, cannot be sustained by itself. @jyanixbach Our supernova had created many elements heavier than Uranium but they have decayed almost entirely by now into lighter elements. The half-life of Uranium as about the same as the age of the Solar System so there is about 50% of it now left, but Plutonium has a much shorter half life (around 700 million years) so it's almost entirely decayed by now and it was less abundant than Uranium to begin with so we almost can't find it on Earth. So there is no "Great Mistery" here.

@SEThatered Anything is possible, however it is highly unlikely. elements are the smallest components of all of matter. Every element is defined by how many protons it has. 1 proton is hydrogen, 2 protons is helium, 8 is oxygen and so on.  After a certain point atoms get too heavy and just can't hold anymore protons and become radioactive and start decomposing. Since you can't really have an atom with half a proton it is unlikely there will be any undiscovered atoms in space.
